values.comments:
LGST 206 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students will engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills.

Nearly all students praised this course, citing it as their “favorite course at Penn / Wharton.” Students found the class to be “a thoroughly exciting and highly stimulating learning experience,” “worthwhile,” and “a must-take for all Penn students.” One student went so far to say that it is “one of those courses (and professors) that can fundamentally change your outlook on the world around you.” 

Professor Shell was described by students as “extremely articulate and very passionate about his discipline.” Students also appreciated Professor Shell’s “willingness to meet with students and genuine desire to talk to them.”

The only negative feedback about the course related to grading. One student felt that “the quizzes were challenging, and did not seem to test the important parts of the readings.” Another student wished Professor Shell had “provided clearer guidelines for short papers.” However, most students agreed that the “level of fairness in all modes of assessment were upheld.” One student commented that “while it was tough to score well, this will be one of the classes that I don’t mind getting a B because I enjoyed the course content so much and learned a lot.”

LGST 206 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students will engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills.

Students thoroughly enjoyed the course content. Students found the material to be “very practical” and “useful.” Students appreciated how they were not graded on the outcome of their negotiation exercises because it made them more comfortable when trying out a new strategy.

Students also had many positive things to say about Professor Shropshire. In particular, students appreciated how he “makes you immediately feel comfortable with negotiations.” One student described him as “very humble, great voice, and just seems to bring a lot of credibility to the table.”

Students did not find the course to be particularly difficult, but they learned a great deal. One student even categorized the course reading as “engaging and always fun.” One student felt that “the midterm was poorly written, especially for being worth 30% of the semester grade,” but that is the only criticism that the course received.

LGST 206 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students will engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills.

Overall, students were very impressed with this course. One student commented that “this course has been one of the best I've taken at Penn in terms of the level of teaching, the interesting and insightful subject matter, the incredible practical relevance and applicability, and the enjoyment of class and practical exercises,” and similar sentiments were echoed by nearly everyone.

Students thought that Professor Blum was “dynamic,” “engaging,” and an “expert of the course material.” Many students reported that Professor Blum was “one of the greatest teachers [they] ever had.” They also appreciated Professor Blum’s “gift for making the class consistently entertaining.”

While students enjoyed the class and learned a great deal, some found the workload to be heavier than they expected. One student commented that “the class required a lot of work, but it was worth every minute of it,” and this tended to be the theme throughout most student responses. For the most part, students got a lot out of the journal entries but felt that the “length requirement was intimidating.” Some students expressed a dislike for the three quizzes which sometimes seemed to have “multiple correct answers.”

LGST 206 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students will engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills.

Students enjoyed the course and felt that it “teaches valuable skills for the real world.” Students also appreciated Professor Bergman’s policy of not grading the outcomes of negotiation exercises, as it created an incentive to be “reasonable instead of stubborn, and come to a good, realistic outcome.”

Professor Bergman was well liked by his students, who classified him as an “awesome professor,” “extremely engaging,” and “always available to talk.” One student commented that “Professor Bergman is the best teacher I have ever had. He is clearly very experienced in the field and is very adept at conveying his learned knowledge to his students.”

Students seemed to get a lot out of the class, but did not find it to be overly difficult or have too much required work. Requirements included class participation, a take-home midterm examination, an individual paper, and a final group project.
